Another opinion

Though I can understand that the "If X will happen anyway, its better to make it legal" arguement cannot be applied in all cases, there are cases where it is a valid arguement. If a society imposes a very unfair law that violates rights that people believe are natural rights, then large numbers of people might disobey such laws and, where human rights are concerned, they might have a strong case supporting such dissent. 
 
 As an extreme example to illustrate this point, imagine if, in the USA, a law was passed allowing sex only for the purposes of childbearing, and limiting those acts to people under, say, 40 since those are the best childbearing years. (This assumes that the extreme minority who hold such opinions were able to put this into law). Then, I think nearly all would agree that violating such a law, though illegal, would still be morally justified since the law would violate what people hold as certain natural rights. Of course, as with the example of people justifying theft, the great majority of laws do not impose on the strongest held views of natural rights, so very few would argue to abolish those laws. 
 
 The trouble comes where there is a very commonly held view of a natural right that is not shared by all. in this case, I am talking about the natural right to control over ones own body. A very large number of Americans (and others throughout the world) hold this so strongly as a natural right that they would be willing to take illegal actions under certain circumstances in order to protect it. Unfortunately for women with unwanted pregnancies, at some point humans do also acquire the natural right to life. A lot of the discussions we have had in this forum concentrate on when such a right comes into being. I will leave that for another thread. My bottom line is that we, as a society, need to finally come to some consensus about which natural rights are critical, whether the right to ones body is one of those, and how the rights should be balanced.

 I can agree with that. But what I find interesting is that people tend to selectively call it either a "baby" or a "fetus" depending on what makes them feel best at the time, or what fits their politics. People call it a "baby" when they want it to be a baby. ("Doctor, is my baby inside going to be ok"?) But then when people want to avoid thinking of the baby in a personal way, they use clinical terms like fetus, or pregnancy. That, IMO, devalues the baby. If a human life can, at times, have enough value to be called a baby, then it should always have that sort of value.
 
 I was looking at a family planning website recently where they avoided calling it a baby by using the term "pregnancy" even using it as a noun FOR the baby. It said something to the effect of 'this procedure will stop the growth of the pregnancy inside you' or something to that effect. What it really meant is that it will stop the growth of the baby/fetus inside by killing it. I just find it interesting the way that terminology is often watered down or at least changed to fit however someone wants to think about it. It seems to me that if a human life can be valued in ANY context, it should always be treated as such.

I agree with the person who said on this forum (don't know who, sorry) that pro-choicers who choose to use those terms only do it to detach themselves from the real issue, that it is killing a child. They do it so that when they talk to people they can keep the issue focused on the woman and discount the child as just a "fetus". 
 
 
To the woman who doesn't want to carry the growing baby in her womb for 9 months, it certainly is a parasite. It's living off her body, consuming precious bodily fluids and causing weakness of the host...just like fleas on a dog...sucking the blood out of the host's system.

 
 What women have told you this? I'd be interested in knowing what kind of woman would call the child in her womb a parasite. I didn't feel that way. I enjoyed the few short weeks I had with my growing child. Even though I felt like I had run a marathon at the end of the day, felt as if I wanted to throw up looking at any cooked food, I did not consider it a parasite and I think I would be one to know not you.
Aivlis

Jyoshu, I think that places like Planned Parenthood tend to do that because it is a clinic and clinics tend to use more scientific terms. They also do not want to be bombarding young girls who are in trouble with words like "killing your baby", it tends to cause more harm than good. I understand that people need to face responsibilities and reality but sometimes these girls are young, very young. 
 
 Jim, I don't care how many definitions you give me for parasite, I still find it extremely insensitive! How can you as a man tell any woman what or how they feel about a child growing in their womb. Please, give me examples of people calling their own growing child a parasite because I think those people have some real issues. Use that word if you like but it reveals a lot about what kind of person you are Jim.
jyoshu

Jyoshu, I think that places like Planned Parenthood tend to do that because it is a clinic and clinics tend to use more scientific terms. They also do not want to be bombarding young girls who are in trouble with words like "killing your baby", it tends to cause more harm than good. I understand that people need to face responsibilities and reality but sometimes these girls are young, very young.

 
 I can see your point on the 2nd issue. But I also think that watering it down is doing these young women a disservice, because it's sheltering them from reality. But regarding your statement PP uses clinical terms because it's a clinical environment doesn't seem to hold up since OB/GYN doctors are also in a clinical environment when they tell excited mothers about the health of the their "baby" and rarely use the term "fetus."
Aivlis

Well jyoshu you have to consider the circumstances. When a women goes into see her OB/GYN she is probably more than likely excited to be pregnant and wants to carry the child to term, therefore they use terms like "baby". On the other hand, when a girl goes into PP she usually is going in for B.C., the morning after pill, pregnancy tests, physicals and abortions. Usually things that either prevent or terminate a pregnancy. Those different circumstances require different handling, therefore different terminology. I do agree that people need to realize mistakes and face reality, I'm a firm believer in personal responsibility. However, even those most responsible still make mistakes or have accidents.
jim's trucking

No, but one of the reasons we keep coming back to this forum is to see other peoples opinions and debate on particular issues. I said what I said because I think that a lot of what you say can be very inflamatory, like calling a fetus a parasite. 
I'm not afraid of being inflammatory...like when I refer to some vermin as Islamo-fascist swine.
 
 Please tell me how a fetus, in view of the definitions previously posted, is not a parasite.
 
 
 
 

 Well abortions are legal for many reasons besides the fact that people are going to do them anyway. Those things you listed are not legal for obvious reasons. Therefore, you cannot just apply the same argument for things that have absolutely nothing to do with each other. Where exactly is this ridiculous argument supposed to get you?
I believe your conclusion is invalid. The fact that fraud and abortion have nothing to do with each other does not mean that similar logic cannot be administered when considering whether they should be legal or not.
 
 Just as the fact that a natural tendency to commit fraud is not reason to legalize fraud, the natural tendency to have abortions is not reason to legalize abortions.
 
 
 

 You're also not required to believe the earth is round but do you? Just because something feels no pain does not make the act any less tragic or harmful. I am very on the fence on whether or not I think abortions are cruel or not. However, I can understand why people do feel that way and don't blame them. During mine I felt cruel, guilty etc. I still knew that my decision was the right one though, it all comes down to what you want with your life and I believe that the life of the woman comes first.
 You mentioned earlier that you are pro-choice for "many reasons". Can you name them?
 
 
 
 
 

 That isn't my point. My point is that I don't deny the fact that a fetus would have eventually been a child. I can't stand people who are so insensitive to call it "tissue" or "worm" or "parasite". I agree with the person who said on this forum (don't know who, sorry) that pro-choicers who choose to use those terms only do it to detach themselves from the real issue, that it is killing a child. They do it so that when they talk to people they can keep the issue focused on the woman and discount the child as just a "fetus". 
You obviously haven't been convinced that the "thing" growing in the mother's womb is at first simply a mass of cells, clumped together and dividing occasionally to become a larger mass of cells that EVENTUALLY will form into different body parts.
 
 I recognize a distinct difference between a glob of cells and a substantially developed fetus (with fingers, toes, ears, eyes, pumping heart, brain, etc.)
 
 Killing the initial mass of cells is not cruel or inhumane. Killing a well developed fetus likely is. That's why I draw the window of opportunity (to abort) as the first tri-mester. Up until the closing of the window, the mother should have the right to abort. After that, she should be required to follow through with the birth unless her life becomes threatened by the continuing pregnancy. 
 
 
 

 What women have told you this? I'd be interested in knowing what kind of woman would call the child in her womb a parasite. I didn't feel that way. I enjoyed the few short weeks I had with my growing child. Even though I felt like I had run a marathon at the end of the day, felt as if I wanted to throw up looking at any cooked food, I did not consider it a parasite and I think I would be one to know not you.
If you look carefully at the definition provided, you will see that a parasite is not required to be unwelcomed.
 
 A woman who does not want to carry or give birth to the baby considers it an unwanted parasite. A woman who wants to go full term and have a beautiful child is carrying a parasitic blessing. The growing mass within the women's womb is a parasite whether it is wanted or not. Those who want the baby will not refer to it as a parasite, but it is one nonetheless.
Sigma

That surely wasn't the logic. It was a statement but there is no logic in a statement such as that. The other presented an argument for pro-choice which would have to have a conclusion, a logic, and some underlying basis for reaching that conclusion based on the logic.

 
 You assumed the conclusion was "abortion should be legal because it will happen anyway". Whatever your problem with this conclusion is, extending it to other cases, such as theft, is not valid.
 
 
no, I don't know what evidence you are talking about. This would make no sense anyway and would be the first time every that something becoming legal sparked a decrease in that activity (as opposed to consequences of that activity). Not to mention abortion wasn't even illegal in all states.

 
 I'm not sure what you're trying to say here. I didn't say there was a decrease in the number of abortions, I'm saying that abortion becoming legal didn't spark a great deal of increase just because it was now legal. This is evidenced by the birth rate between before Roe and after Roe. The legality affected other things that could have lead to an increase, but the legality itself didn't increase the number of abortions done. Logically, were abortion to suddenly become illegal, those who desire abortions would still desire them and would likely be able to acquire them, as evidenced by the fact that abortions were done despite the law before, and techniques are even easier to employ now. The numbers would likely decrease, but I doubt very far.
 
 
You could easily stop doctors from doing it. Doctors are caught providing drugs (illegally) all the time...this would be no different. As for "common sense"...why wasn't that used in the above statement about abortion going down?

 
 Common sense was used. How many doctors were caught performing abortions when it was illegal? Not terribly many, from what I've seen. Combine this with the ability to perform a self-abortion and the information to do so is freely disseminated and you have a law that is very difficult to enforce, practically speaking.
 
 
Still irrelevant to the argument presented by the orginal poster. If you wish to discuss this point (whether a law should be created if hard to enforce) than start another topic.

 
 We are assuming that point here, Steve, and was part of my original post that you replied to. The entire point of whether the law would be practical to enforce assumes that an unenforcable law (without draconian measures, at least) should not exist.
 
 
Appeal to fear...some will even have a fallacy of "dooms day".

 
 It would be so if I said: Given the demand, unregulated illegal supply would skyrocket and police would be completely unable to stop women from performing abortions upon themselves with ascorbic acid or merely throwing themselves upon chairs, thereforce abortion needs to be kept legal
 
 I did not. These facts make such a law unworkable, practically speaking. If a solution is unworkable then another should be considered.
Aivlis

I believe your conclusion is invalid. The fact that fraud and abortion have nothing to do with each other does not mean that similar logic cannot be administered when considering whether they should be legal or not.

 
 I'm glad you don't run this countries legal system.
 
 
A woman who does not want to carry or give birth to the baby considers it an unwanted parasite.

 
 How exactly do you know what a women considers her baby? It may be unwanted but it does not mean that she considers it a parasite. It might very well be a parasite by definition, but it is also many other things...like a human being. My problem with the usage of the word parasite are the connotations that go along with that word, usually things like bugs and worms that make you sick, not a growing fetus. 
 
 
You mentioned earlier that you are pro-choice for "many reasons". Can you name them?

 Well, I believe that a woman should have control over her own body and whether or not she will carry a pregnancy to term. I believe that government should stay out of people's personal health issues, that politicians should not be making judgements on medical issues. I don't like how religous pro-lifers think that they can force their morality onto me, or that they think i'm a sinner or going to hell for how I believe. I'm pro-choice because I understand how many different circumstances are involved with women who want to terminate a pregnancy. Lastly, I wouldn't feel right telling other people what to do with their lives, which is why i'm not pro-life. I also don't consider myself to be completely on the pro-choice side either because of the way they handle a lot of issues.
jim's trucking

You assumed the conclusion was "abortion should be legal because it will happen anyway". Whatever your problem with this conclusion is, extending it to other cases, such as theft, is not valid.
He rightly inferred that the original post held to that 'logic'...which is invalid...when applied to abortion or any other issue.
jim's trucking

I'm glad you don't run this countries legal system.
The fact that I recognize that a false logic train should not be applied to ANY issue has nothing to do with how I would run this country's legal system if I were in position to do just that.
 
 
 

 How exactly do you know what a women considers her baby? It may be unwanted but it does not mean that she considers it a parasite. It might very well be a parasite by definition, but it is also many other things...like a human being. My problem with the usage of the word parasite are the connotations that go along with that word, usually things like bugs and worms that make you sick, not a growing fetus. 
I understand your reaction to the word. However, its definition (2: in the posted dictionary version) fits exactly in this case. The fetus is a parasite. The growing baby is a parasite until it exits the womb and breathes on its own.
 
 Whether the pregnant party has sense enough to recognize that she's carrying a parasite or not has nothing to do with the fact that she is doing so. Whether she refers to it as a parasite or not also has nothing to do with the fact that she IS CARRYING A PARASITE.
 
 

 Well, I believe that a woman should have control over her own body and whether or not she will carry a pregnancy to term. I believe that government should stay out of people's personal health issues, that politicians should not be making judgements on medical issues. I don't like how religous pro-lifers think that they can force their morality onto me, or that they think i'm a sinner or going to hell for how I believe. I'm pro-choice because I understand how many different circumstances are involved with women who want to terminate a pregnancy. Lastly, I wouldn't feel right telling other people what to do with their lives, which is why i'm not pro-life. I also don't consider myself to be completely on the pro-choice side either because of the way they handle a lot of issues.
Commendable.
 
 What lot of issues do the pro-choicers handle badly...in your opinion?
Sigma

He rightly inferred that the original post held to that 'logic'...which is invalid...when applied to abortion or any other issue.

 
 This would have to be shown, not assumed, to be invalid when applied to abortion. That logic can be applied to one issue without applying to others. Applying it to other issues in an attempt to invalidate that logic is, itself, invalid.
Aivlis

Jim, you talk as if a fetus can only be described or defined as a "parasite". What about human, child, fetus, embryo, baby. Why not use a word that is less likely to anger or confuse people, a fetus is rarely described as a parasite. 
 
 
What lot of issues do the pro-choicers handle badly...in your opinion?

 
 Well both sides on the extreme end can sometimes be extremely deterogatory and insulting. My issues with pro-choicers is their refusal to accept that a growing fetus is actually a baby, a living human being. I do not care if there are no nerves or brain cells yet, it's still a human baby. I guess that's really, I would be against any pro-choicer who wants to impose their views on anybody else or uses unethical means to acheive their goal.
jim's trucking

This would have to be shown, not assumed, to be invalid when applied to abortion. That logic can be applied to one issue without applying to others. Applying it to other issues in an attempt to invalidate that logic is, itself, invalid.
Here is what the OP said:
 
 

 [snip] Abortions are still going to happen whether they are outlawed or not. I would just rather have them done safely in a doctor's office then with a clothes hanger at home.
If you do not infer this to mean that abortions should be legal because they are going to happen anyway, what do you think it means?
 
 To have them "done safely in a doctor's office" suggests legality. Therefore preferring them to happen as described suggests a preference to legality since they are going to happen whether legal or not.
 
 This can be reduced (as Steeeeve did once) to:
 
...
 "if you make X illegal and X will still happen if illegal than X should stay legal"....

 
 It is an invalid argument regardless of what "X" is.
Aivlis

It is an invalid argument regardless of what "X" is.

 
 I think you're dead wrong here. What if you don't think that "X" is a bad or should be considered a crime? Consider prohibition, people still drank...crime skyrocketed etc. Only when it became legal again could it be regulated and handled more efficiently. 
 
 Nobody said that just because abortion will happen anyway if made illegal that that argument could be made for everything else. Steve was the one that brought this whole X thing up (which doesn't surprise me). You can't just assume that you can look at an issue blindly, you have to consider each circumstance and situation.
Steeeeve

Though I can understand that the "If X will happen anyway, its better to make it legal" arguement cannot be applied in all cases, there are cases where it is a valid arguement. If a society imposes a very unfair law that violates rights that people believe are natural rights, then large numbers of people might disobey such laws and, where human rights are concerned, they might have a strong case supporting such dissent. 
 Yet the reason for getting rid of the law is that the law is unjust not that "people are doing it anyway".
Joe@actsii

To the woman who doesn't want to carry the growing baby in her womb for 9 months, it certainly is a parasite. It's living off her body, consuming precious bodily fluids and causing weakness of the host...just like fleas on a dog...sucking the blood out of the host's system.

 
 If you are not just using rhetoric to get your point across and you really feel this way, I think you are a sick individual. emoticon_xdonno
Steeeeve

I think you're dead wrong here. What if you don't think that "X" is a bad or should be considered a crime? Consider prohibition, people still drank...crime skyrocketed etc. Only when it became legal again could it be regulated and handled more efficiently. 
 
 Nobody said that just because abortion will happen anyway if made illegal that that argument could be made for everything else. Steve was the one that brought this whole X thing up (which doesn't surprise me). You can't just assume that you can look at an issue blindly, you have to consider each circumstance and situation.

 
 The logic makes no sense...you don't have to consider circumstance. Just look at the argument and break it down.
 
 "If abortion is made illegal people will still have abortions but they will be unsafe and thus abortion should be legal and safe".
 
 In this argument you have a premise that 1) abortions will still happen if illegal and 2) unsafe abortions are a bad thing (implied). What you are trying to do is throw in other arguments such as "abortion being illegal is a bad thing" and "unsafe abortions are worse than unsafe theft...etc". Both of these are not implied nor are they part of the argument. The argument rests soley on the fact that someone will still happen if made illegal. Now lets use this logic again.... "if insider trading is made illegal(which it is) people will still do insider trading and thus insider trading should be legal". If you want to include both premises you would use the theft example shown earlier. Now do they both meet the standards set from the orginal premise? Yes. Theft (or insider trading) will still happen if illegal. Unsafe theft is a bad thing (no one wants the C-store man to be dead). Without any other qualifiers the same logic test applies and the conclusion must be same. This is pretty basic logic if you decide to take a philosophy course at a college.
 
 Now if you say in your argument that there is nothing worse (or not many things worse) than an unsafe abortion then the theft example can't be used and the point actually makes sense to people. You simply implied this part instead of actually looking at what was written. Saying "it will happen anyway" is not enough to make a convincing argument.
 
 
What if you don't think that "X" is a bad or should be considered a crime
 NOT PART OF THE ARGUMENT. Come on now... your point here is not that "it will happen anyway" but that the law is unjust.
jim's trucking

I think you're dead wrong here. What if you don't think that "X" is a bad or should be considered a crime? Consider prohibition, people still drank...crime skyrocketed etc. Only when it became legal again could it be regulated and handled more efficiently. 
 
 Nobody said that just because abortion will happen anyway if made illegal that that argument could be made for everything else. Steve was the one that brought this whole X thing up (which doesn't surprise me). You can't just assume that you can look at an issue blindly, you have to consider each circumstance and situation.
No matter what emotional issues you tie to "X" in the invalid logic train, the logic remains invalid.
 
 In order to determine if something ("X") should be legal or not, you consider the pros and cons of legalization and prohibition. You weigh all the factors (pros and cons) then you vote on the proposed restricting laws. 
 
 You DO NOT consider the fact that some people are going to do it anyway whether you legalize it or not. If that consideration has any weight in the abortion issue, it should carry the same weight in consideration of any other issue regarding legalization of a common occurence.
 
 I do not understand why you cannot understand this simple common sense logic.
Aivlis

What exactly am I not understanding?
 
 
No matter what emotional issues you tie to "X" in the invalid logic train, the logic remains invalid.

 
 We disagree. There is a difference between allowing rape to be legal because men are going to do it anyway and allowing abortion to be legal because women are going to do it anyway. How can you not see that? Even if you think that the logic of allowing something to be legal because people are going to do it anyway is invalid it doesn't make it any less real. 
 
 I don't see why some people on this board keep insisting that just because ONE aspect of keeping abortion legal is that "it will happen anyway" that that small argument can be applied to anything? NOBODY EVER SAID THAT
 
 
In order to determine if something ("X") should be legal or not, you consider the pros and cons of legalization and prohibition. You weigh all the factors (pros and cons) then you vote on the proposed restricting laws.

 
 One of the cons of prohibition of abortion is that people are going to have them anyway and that will lead to unsafe abortion practices. That is only one FACTOR that I am weighing, there are many others for keeping abortion legal. 
 
 
You DO NOT consider the fact that some people are going to do it anyway whether you legalize it or not. If that consideration has any weight in the abortion issue, it should carry the same weight in consideration of any other issue regarding legalization of a common occurence.

 
 YES YOU DO. You cannot just ignore a huge part of the issue just because you don't agree with the logic! 
 
 I think that this logic should be applied to any issue where illegalization makes that practice unsafe for people, such as abortion. NOT rape, incest, theft, murder etc......
jim's trucking

If you are not just using rhetoric to get your point across and you really feel this way, I think you are a sick individual. emoticon_xdonno
You are entitled to think as you please.
 
 Perhaps you have formed this opinion due to emotional sympathy for the human fetus that you do not have for the blood sucking fleas.
 
 The statement I made merely parallels them both in the category of taking strength from the host. They both do this because they are both parasites, living off the blood of the host organism. In the case of the fetus, the host is a human female. In the case of the fleas, the host is a mangy yard dog.
 
 Now I suppose you will make the mistake of saying I'm equating expectant mothers to mangy yard dogs. You would be just as wrong as you were in taking offense with the analogous comparison of fetuses and fleas.
 
 It was nothing but an analogy. I think very highly of women, embryos, fetuses, womb-bound growing babies, newborns, rug rats, toddlers, tricycle motors, little leaguers, teeny-boppers, highschool cheerleaders, debutantes, newly weds, divorcees, puppies and mangy yard dogs. I have seen a very entertaining flea circus. However, sometimes you have to pick fleas off the dog...sometimes you have to separate fetuses from women who don't want them.
Aivlis

It was nothing but an analogy. I think very highly of women, embryos, fetuses, womb-bound growing babies, newborns, rug rats, toddlers, tricycle motors, little leagers, teeny-boppers, highschool cheerleaders, debutantes, newly weds, divorcees, puppies and mangy yard dogs. I have seen a very entertaining flea circus. However, sometimes you have to pick fleas off the dog...sometimes you have to separate fetuses from women who don't want them.

 
 You're a funny guy Jim. emoticon_xgood
jitobear

I think very highly of women, embryos, fetuses, womb-bound growing babies, newborns, rug rats, toddlers, tricycle motors, little leagers, teeny-boppers, highschool cheerleaders, debutantes, newly weds, divorcees, puppies and mangy yard dogs. I have seen a very entertaining flea circus.

 
 What about cranky old moms?
jim's trucking

What about cranky old moms?
Yes, I love you, too!:)
jitobear

Yes, I love you, too!:)

 
 YAH! emoticon_xhoho 
 
 You are my favorite conservative.
Sigma

Yet the reason for getting rid of the law is that the law is unjust not that "people are doing it anyway".

 
 

 In order to determine if something ("X") should be legal or not, you consider the pros and cons of legalization and prohibition. You weigh all the factors (pros and cons) then you vote on the proposed restricting laws. 
 
 You DO NOT consider the fact that some people are going to do it anyway whether you legalize it or not. If that consideration has any weight in the abortion issue, it should carry the same weight in consideration of any other issue regarding legalization of a common occurence.

 
 As Aivlis has said, if the law is practically unworkable or unenforcable that is one aspect that should be considered as a con of the law. If theft could not be significantly curtailed with laws restricting theft then an alternate means should be considered.
Shooterandproud

good thing this argument has never been done!...oh wait.
 
 With that logic we should make everything legal. You are much better off making theft legal and safe (no more guns needed!) than to have it illegal and dangerous.

 
 Completely moot comparison.
 
 Theft laws minimize theft.
 
 Murder laws minimize murder.
 
 Abortion laws make women do it unsafely at home.
 
 I have statistics on my side, you have, um..., not much.
 
 Look at narcotics laws. Working like a charm eh?

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  An Argument for Pro Choice
